title.narrative: Strengthening LGBT HRDs in East Africa

description.narrative:
Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender and Intersex (LGBTI+) people in Tanzania and those in the Kenyan Coastal city of Mombasa in Kenya face similar challenges ranging from social stigmatisation to lack of poor networks in which they can mobilise for action and carry out advocacy for protection of their rights. They also share a common language, Swahili, which is used by their communities to further stigmatise them using derogatory names and expressions meant to trivialise their existence. The project entitled #Together we are stronger! Strengthening LGBTI Human Rights Defenders# Networks in Eastern Africa# will bring together different LGBTI+ Human Rights Defenders (HRDs) across Kenya and Tanzania, engage local and national authorities to contribute to the promotion and protection the human rights of LGBTI+ people, and particular those of HRDs and their Right to Defend Human Rights (RHDR). The action will also work with religious leaders, doctors, lawyers, and police forces who all have exclusionary and discriminatory perceptions and actions towards LGBTI+ people.
The project seeks to address judicial authorities as they can outlaw governmental decisions through their judicial rulings. The Kenyan judicial authorities are actually already acting with a positive attitude towards LGBTI, so it is crucial to seize this opportunity to extend this improvement to the rest of the region. The project will specifically aim at strengthening the preventive protection of LGBTI HRDs, and their organisations; it willtake a preventive protection approach, encompassing physical and digital security and well-being. Moreover, since protection is enhanced when HRDs are not isolated, the action will also build and strengthen LGBTI+ HRDs networks at national and regional levels, with the aim of giving a common voice to LGBTI+ peacefully defending their rights and dignity. Ultimately, the project promotes the creation and strengthening of these networks to open new spaces for policy reforms, to seize legislative and judicialopportunities, and to raise awareness about discrimination and violations of LGBTI#s human rights in the region.
The project contributes to raise awareness on issues such as Sexual Orientation, Gender Identity and Expression and Sexual Characteristics(SOGIESC), the human rights situation of LGBTI+ people in general, and specifically ofthe LGBTI HRDs, and the levels of violence and discrimination they face on a daily basis, including dangerous practices like forcedanal examination and forced genitalsurgery for intersex people. Moreover, the project wants to "take out" LGBTI+ HRDs form isolation, connecting them in networks at the national level, in their home countries but also at the regional level, given the very similarthreats faced by LGBTI+ in Kenya and Tanzania. Tanzania LGBTI HRDs can acquire important knowledge form their Kenyan colleagues andmake the difference in their own country.

participating-org.narrative:
Persons Marginalized and Aggrieved (PEMA) Kenya is an organisation formed in 2008 that thrives advancing the human rights of genderand sexual minorities, specifically in Mombasa. PEMA Kenya was founded within a context of tragedy when a young gay man, shunned and stigmatized by his family because of his sexual orientation, who died in May 2008. There was no one to honour his memory or give him a decent burial. Stunned by such a level of loathing for gay people, a group of gay men in Mombasa came together to find a decentand dignified resting place for him. It was this support of one of their own that gave birth to the Brotherhood, which evolved intoPEMA Kenya.
PEMA-Kenya is a membership-based organisation founded in 2008 whose work is premised uponcreating an enabling environment for its members and the general population to thrive. It is a lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex, queer (LGBTIQ)-led organisation that works with LGBTIQ individuals and communities as well as stakeholders seeking to bridge the gap that exists between the general population and gender and sexual minorities (GSM).
PEMA Kenya had its first three-year strategic planning process in 2012, resulting in a strategic plan that saw the organisation develop partnershipsand networks, and engage in work with institutionsthat have been considered perpetrators of violence towards gender and sexual minorities. PEMA Kenya#s work with the police, religious leaders, media, healthcare providers, and advocates of the High CourtofKenya pushed the organisation to realise that there was still great need to reach out to people from all walks of life and provide them with knowledge on gender and sexual minority issues.
